A thing I've found useful for glaring hurling is throwing a pinch of salt in my mouth if things are getting ready to blow.

I've noticed vomiting is generally preceded by my mouth watering *a lot*. I think what's probably happening is the mouth is getting ready for it by pumping lots of fluids to the various muscles involved in gagging, and the salt sucks a bunch of it out, disrupting the process.

I really only use this if I've triggered my gag reflex, like accidentally water-piking the back of my throat or something like that. For vomiting driven by stomach upsets or food poisoning, I've found it overall just better to find a toilet, and let it happen.

And if you want to super charge your chicken soup, doing it Greek style and add egg and lemon to the soup. The citrus helps your vitamin C, and the egg gives it some more nutrition, especially if you're starting it from soup in a can.

While true avgolemono soup is supposed to be carefully whipped together to give it its characteristic mouth feel, you really can just scramble and egg into the soup when you're just not feeling up to it.

As a massage therapist YES PLEASE GET MASSAGE REGULARLY. Not just be-cause that's how I make money, but be-cause is not only helpful in and of itself (super helpful in many cases), but the therapy builds upon itself. My regulars who couldn't get massage for several months or longer through the pandemic all came in saying that their pain and many other issues got much worse over that period, and once they started getting massage again it got better. There are so many factors involved I absolutely would not say that massage is the only key here, but it's definitely a prominent trend. Plus, a huge benefit of massage is that it actually teaches you about your body and helps you learn how to tell when you just need to move out get a massage, and when you should go to a doctor

I have fibromyalgia, tertiary pain patterns from trigger points, and synesthesia, so it may just be that my nerves are messed up, but... another weird thing that temporarily (but extremely rapidly) clears up my stuffy nose when I get that is... orgasming. In regards to the chicken soup thing, I've always just thought that it's because when you boil bones, you release nutrients from the bone marrow into the broth, nutrients you normally don't get because most people don't eat marrow directly from the bones. It's why in Chinese medicinal traditions, bone broth has always been recommended to aging adults to help provide additional nutrients and vitamins to their diet. I don't know to what extent marrow nutrients actually treat nasal congestion in particular, but it's just always been known that getting the most nutrients out of the meat and bones you consume is better than eating just the meat.

Starting in about 1990 I was sick all the time with colds and all the way up to double pneumonia .

In 2016 I got sick again and was in bed for a week with with something that took a Z-Pack to cure up. 3 days later I had 2 strokes with the second being massive. No one know why I took most of the meds I took and since that part of my brain was damaged, neither did I.

We started adding back the drugs and supplements as we figured it out but I had a new one no one nor I knew why I had, Zinc. 2 weeks later I got a new cold and was panicking about it for some reason and I remembered why the Zinc.

I was going to start taking it to see if it would reduce colds a pneumonia for the 1000 time in my life.

I have not even had the sniffers since then. Weather it works or not, in my mind it does so I am calling it a win.

Maybe this is helpful for others.
this is what I love about science. Some things just work yet noone knows why.

In the case of smelling rubbing (Isopropanol.) to relieve nausea, from persona experience with the stuff, I'm pretty sure the reflex to get away from the irritant overrides the reflex to vomit. The brain realises the painful sensation is a danger, and the body must get away, so it tells the stomach to "Hold on, legs get running, lungs pause breathing."

I've always used Olbas oil (brand name) inhaled from a tissue for beating nausea. It's a mixture of several very strong smelling, noxious substances including eucalyptus, clove, levonmenthol and peppermint oil. It's meant to be used as a decongestant, inhaled from a tissue. It smells so strong that a few drops will quickly fill an entire room with its fresh menthol smell. Breathing it directly from the tissue is almost painful, causing a strong sensation of cold in the nasal cavity and throat. It's never failed for me. I always thought it was some kind of distraction, maybe it's more of an interruption!

My parents used to sell wrist bands for sea sickness (nausea) at our boat store. My sister had always suffered from motion sickness, and said that the band really helped. I've used them, to see what they felt like, and there is no pain...just a gentle pressure on that point on the wrist. I suspect there's something going on with the parasympathetic nervous system.
I was also engaged with a woman who was studying Traditional Chinese Medicine (as well as Biochemistry) and she told me the pressure point was identified in TCM.
All these years later, I’m reminded of how I used to cortisol crash after finals and get sick.  Should’ve used chicken soup!

At 8:35 you talk about prolonged effects of high cortisol levels negatively impacting your immune system. That's actually one of the things that former Surgeon General Dr. Vivek Murthy talks about when describing "the epidemic of loneliness".

From an evolutionary perspective, it is as important to avoid social harm as physical harm (being disliked by your band could easily mean not getting to eat thus death) so you respond to pain from both similarly. Chronic loneliness produces the same long term high cortisol levels because of that social pain. Thus it weakens your immune system.

Dr. Murthy examines how society promotes that loneliness and how it suffers from it in his book "Togetherness: The Healing Power of Human Connection in a Sometimes Lonely World" if you want to learn more.

For the past nearly 10 years, I've been finding that it isn't chicken soup exactly that helps symptoms of colds/flus, but simple clear water. Even plain old water that's been boiled/microwaved does wonders. I hypothesize that hot water helps melt away mucous buildup in the throat which would have lead to soar throats. Perhaps if the water is hot enough it might kill some germs, but I can't confirm that. It doesn't cure the illness, but it really helps reduce the symptoms for me. Most people find the idea of drinking plain hot water kind of disgusting though, and refuse to do it. Some will have to at least resort to adding tea & honey or something to be palatable to them, but I go with just pure hot water (note I don't drink hot water from the tap/faucet, because hot water from the tap seems to bring some funkiness to the water). I think hot chicken soup idea can act similarly, but obviously it can be more interesting to eat as it has a mild, and light richness (chicken fat oil), with slippery noodles that won't scratch the throat as it goes down.
Oh, the advantage of hot water over chicken soup IMO is that you can constantly drink hot water throughout the entire day, but it's not practical to eat chicken soup throughout the entire day. I'd either get full from chicken soup or I'd get tired of eating chicken soup if I tried. The constant flow of hot water over a gunky throat helps to keep your throat clear & alleviated of pain for the entire day. I recommend trying it.

Long ago in college (20-30 years back, now) I had a biology lab supervisor who theorized that the chicken soup thing was also good for you when you have a rhinovirus simply because you're taking in easily-digestible, liquid suspensions of nutrients that your body really needs while fighting off pathogens. Basically, you're giving it a full spectrum of things it needs in a medium that's possibly the best for getting those things into your system: fast.

He didn't cite any sources and it may have just been a considered opinion, but I've always wondered if that's right or not.

I mean it sounds logical but I've also learned that lots of things that make intuitive sense aren't right...

Thoughts?

The most important thing to remember is that healthiness is more important than comfort. You're trying to shake someone off the top of your car, the LAST thing you want is a nice comfy drive. If you're too hot, take a hot shower, if youre too cold, take a cold shower. Don't try to balance out your "shaking", trying to exacerbate it! Don't take multivitamins, you dont want a balanced blood chemistry. You're trying to screw with the chemical parameters of your body as much as you can. Because you are big and you will survive, but the small things inside you wont be so lucky. Your body is making you sick as a defense response, help your body by enhancing your defense response, don't help the invader by hampering the defense response. A tip for anyone having a hay fever in the spring. If you are at home and have a runny nose from a hay fever, and you dont have your prefered pills at hand, and want to do something important RIGHT NOW (like run to the nearest pharmacy) - cut a clove of fresh garlic, put it really close to your nasal passages without actually touching it, obviously, and inhale deeply. For the next 10-15 minutes you'll be fine and with a much drier nose.

Hey Licensed Massage Therapist (in 3 states) here with an important correction. Do not get a massage when sick!! Getting a massage when sick (if you magically find a therapist that will take you) will compound your symptoms and make you feel worse. Currently the theory behind why this is that as we massage, we are effecting the interstitial fluid flow in your body. This increases circulation and pushes metabolic waste through your body which can overwhelm your system while it is already fighting the virus. Please Dont Get A Massage When Sick! Come in after you are no longer contagious or experiencing symptoms!

At the very first sign of a cold (usually sore itchy throat) start taking Airborne. It will drastically reduce the severity and duration of the cold. It helps keep you functional instead of that incessant feeling of malaise. If you start taking it too late it won't have any effect. And also, if you stop taking it too soon you probably will experience the worst common cold you've ever had.

On top of this drink plenty of water and get LOTS of sleep. Sleep allows your body to put all of it's energy into fighting off the cold. The more sleep you get the faster you'll get over your cold. CBD gummies and indica would work great during this time to keep you nice and relaxed.

The pain gate signal theory actually makes sense from a biological perspective, it may be a response to help us focus on the most important signals first. Or focus on the most pressing pain at the moment. If you are already in pain it may be important for us to recognize new or novel pain, and so helps us focus on why we are experiencing that new or novel pain. In this case we're basically hacking pain, but I could totally see a reason for it to exist.

Also, stretching has been proven to reduce pain. Scientists think it’s because tense muscles can increase the pressure on painful nerves, and may intensify pain signals from that area, and may even prevent you body from sending healing cells like white blood cells to the area..  Stretching helps relax the muscles and free up the needed pathways to help promote healing and relieve the burden on nerve cells.
